MacArthur Foundation|MacArthur Foundation]]|language=en|date=1 September 2005}} * 2013: [[Aspen Art Museum]] Aspen Award for Art (Aspen, CO) * 2016: Art in General Visionary Artist Honoree (New York, NY){{cite news|title=Visionary Awards 2016: 35th Anniversary Gala|url=http://www.artingeneral.org/exhibitions/608|work=Art in General|date=11 April 2016}} ;Membership * 2011-2014: [[U.S. Commission of Fine Arts]]{{cite web|title=Teresita Fernández: CFA Service: 2011–2014|url=https://www.cfa.gov/about-cfa/who-we-are/teresita-fernandez|website=[[U.S. Commission of Fine Arts]]|language=en}} * 2016: U.S. Latinx Arts Futures Symposium, Project Director{{cite web|last1=Fernández|first1=Teresita|title=Teresita Fernández, Welcome Remarks|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RxODErjH86A|website=U.S. Latinx Arts Futures Symposium|format=Video|date=9 November 2016}} == Recognition == In 2007, established curator [[Lisa Corrin]] of [[Northwestern University]] called Fernández "one of the best-kept secrets in the contemporary-art world."{{cite news|last1=Stringfield|first1=Anne|title=People Are Talking About: Art. The Dazzle: Teresita Fernández makes art that is structurally elegant, thoughtfully compelling, and absolutely luminous|url=http://images.exhibit-e.com/www_lehmannmaupin_com/b719931f.pdf|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=April 2007|page=270}} In 2011, [[President Obama]] appointed Fernández to the serve on the [[U.S. Commission of Fine Arts]], a federal panel that advises the President, Congress, and governmental agencies on national matters of design and aesthetics. She is the first Latina to serve on the Commission, and the second person of Latino heritage to serve on the CFA in its over 100-year history. Forty years before her appointment, the last Cuban Ambassador to the United States [[Nicolas Arroyo]] sat on the panel from 1971 to 1976. In May 2013, Fernández gave the keynote commencement speech at her alma mater, [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]. Fernández's address was called "On Amnesia, Broken Pottery, and the Inside of a Form." to the graduating class at her alma mater, [[Virginia Commonwealth University]]'s School of the Arts, was cited by [[Maria Popova]]'s blog [[Brain Pickings]] as one of the greatest commencement addresses of all time. Fernández's speech highlighted the values of not giving up, accepting failure and change as a positive, and keeping integrity with accompanied success. Fernandez also offered ten tips for the graduates for help on the creative journey, including 1) Art requires time; 4) Not every project will survive; and 6) "When people say your work is good, do two things: first, don't believe them. Second, ask them, 'why?'" One of the more significant quotes of the keynote speech helped provide insight into Fernández's philosophy that governs her artwork: {{quote|1=I was enamored with the idea of how what seemed broken, discarded, useless was transformed into a meaningful gesture… We are conditioned to think that what is broken is lost, or useless or a setback, and so when we set out with big ambitions we don't necessarily recognize what the next graduation is supposed to look like. Unlearning everything you learned in college is just an exercise in learning to recognize how the fragments and small bits lead to something that is much more than the sum of its parts.{{cite news|last1=Popova|first1=Maria|title=What It Really Takes to Be an Artist: MacArthur Genius Teresita Fernández's Magnificent Commencement Address|url=https://www.brainpickings.org/2014/12/29/teresita-fernandez-commencement-address/|work=[[Brain Pickings]]|date=29 December 2014}}}} Fernández parting point could also be considered her most poignant – a reminder that being human is the wider circle within which being an artist resides, and that our art is always the combinatorial product of the fragments of who we are, of our combinatorial character. {{quote|1=Being an artist is not just about what happens when you are in the studio. The way you live, the people you choose to love and the way you love them, the way you vote, the words that come out of your mouth… will also become the raw material for the art you make.}} == Personal life == Fernández has lived and worked in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] since 1997. She has two children. == Selected solo exhibitions == * 1995: "Real/More Real." The '''''Dîner des trois empereurs''''' or '''Three Emperors Dinner''' was a [[banquet]] held at [[Café Anglais (Paris)|Café Anglais]] in [[Paris]], [[France]] on 7 June 1867. It consisted of 16 [[Course (food)|courses]] with eight wines served over eight hours. ==Overview== The Three Emperors Dinner was prepared by chef [[Adolphe Dugléré]] at the request of [[William I, German Emperor|King William I of Prussia]] who frequented the cafe during the [[Exposition Universelle (1867)|Exposition Universelle]]. He requested a meal to be remembered and at which no expense was to be spared for himself and his guests, [[Tsar Alexander II]] of Russia, plus his son the tsarevitch (who later became [[Tsar Alexander III]]), and [[Otto von Bismarck|Prince Otto von Bismarck]]. The cellar master, Claudius Burdel, was instructed to accompany the dishes with the greatest wines in the world, including a [[Louis Roederer|Roederer champagne]] in a [[Cristal (wine)|special]] [[lead glass]] bottle, so Tsar Alexander could admire the bubbles and golden colour.{{cite web|url=http://menus.free.fr/index_fichiers/Page2511.htm |title=Menus d'hier |publisher=Menus.free.fr |date= |accessdate=27 April 2011}} The banquet consisted of 16 courses with eight wines served over eight hours. The cost of the meal was 400 francs per person{{cite book|title=For epicures only|author=Jean Conil|publisher=T.W. Laurie|year=1952|page=47}} (over [[Euro|€]]9,000 in {{CURRENTYEAR}} prices). The high price of the wines served contributed to the high price of the meal. At 1 o'clock in the morning, Tsar Alexander is reported to have complained that the meal had not contained [[foie gras]]. Burdel explained that it was not the custom in French cuisine to eat foie gras in June. The tsar was satisfied with the answer. Each emperor was sent a [[Terrine (food)|terrine]] of foie gras as a gift the following October.{{cite web|url=http://www.latourdargent.com/emblematique/le-foie-gras-des-trois-empereurs|title=Le foie gras des Trois Empereurs|publisher=La Tour d'Argent}} The table used for the banquet and a copy of the menu is on display at [[La Tour d'Argent]] restaurant in Paris.{{cite web|url=http://www.latourdargent.com/histoire?id_page=9|title=La "Dîner des Trois Empereurs|publisher=La Tour d'Argent|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110805055006/http://www.latourdargent.com/histoire?id_page=9|archivedate=2011-08-05|df=}} ==Menu== The menu included the following, among the 16 courses: {| align=right border="1" cellpadding="40" style="text-align:center; margin-left:1.6em;" |- | '''MENU'''
'''''Potages''''' ''Impératrice''
''Fontanges'' '''''Relevés''''' ''Soufflé à la reine''
''Filets de sole à la vénitienne''
''Escalope de turbot au gratin''
''Selle de mouton purée Bretonne'' '''''Entrées''''' ''Poulet à la portugaise''
''Pâté chaud de cailles''
''Homard à la parisienne''
'''''Digérer'''''
''Sorbets au champagne'' '''''Rôts''''' ''Canetons à la rouennaise''
''Ortolans sur canapés'' '''''Entremets''''' ''Aubergines à l'espagnole''
''Asperges en branches''
''Cassolette princesse'' '''''Dessert''''' ''Bombe glacée''
''Fruit'' '''''VINS''''' ''Madère retour de l'Inde 1810''
''Xérès 1821''
''Châteaux d'Yquem 1847''
''Chambertin 1846''
''Châteaux Margaux 1847''
''Château Latour 1847''
''Châteaux Lafite 1848''
''Champagne Roederer frappé''
|} '''''Potage impératrice''''' consists of a [[chicken stock]] thickened with [[tapioca]] and finished with [[Egg (food)|egg]] [[yolk]]s and [[cream]], to which [[poaching (cooking)|poached]] rounds of [[chicken]] [[forcemeat]], [[cockscombs]], [[rooster|cocks]]' [[kidney (food)|kidney]]s and green [[pea]]s are added.
'''''Potage fontanges''''' is a [[purée]] of fresh peas diluted with [[consommé]] with the addition of a ''[[chiffonade]]'' of [[sorrel]] and sprigs of [[chervil]].''[[Larousse Gastronomique]]'' (1961), Crown Publishers (''Translated from the French, Librairie Larousse, Paris (1938)'')
'''''Soufflé à la reine''''' is a chicken [[soufflé]] with [[truffle]]s
'''''[[Venetian sauce|Sauce vénitienne]]''''' is a [[sauce]] of [[white wine]], [[tarragon]] [[vinegar]], [[shallot]]s and chervil, mounted with [[butter]] and finished with chopped chervil and tarragon.[[August Escoffier]] (1907), ''[[Le Guide Culinaire|Le Guide culinaire]]''
'''''Selle de mouton purée Bretonne''''' is saddle of [[mutton]] with a purée of [[broad bean]]s bound with [[Breton sauce]].
'''''Poulet à la portugaise''''' is whole chicken roasted with a covering of [[adobo]] [[paste (food)|paste]] consisting of [[tomato]], [[red bell pepper]], [[garlic]], [[origanum]], [[paprika]], [[cayenne pepper]], [[brown sugar]], [[lemon juice]], white wine, chicken stock and [[olive oil]], stuffed with tomato flavoured [[rice]].
'''''Pâté chaud de cailles''''' is warm [[pâté]] of [[quail]].
'''''Homard à la parisienne''''' is [[lobster]] cooked in [[court bouillon]], cut into slices and glazed with [[aspic]], with a [[garnish (food)|garnish]] of tomatoes stuffed with a [[macédoine]] of [[vegetable]]s, dressed with a mixture of [[mayonnaise]] and aspic and garnished with sliced truffle.
'''''Canetons à la rouennaise''''' is a dish of [[roasting|roast]] [[duck (food)|duckling]] stuffed with [[forcemeat]]. The legs and breasts are removed, the legs are grilled and the breasts are thinly sliced and arranged around the stuffing. The remaining carcass is pressed in a poultry press to extract all the juices and is added to a [[Rouennaise sauce]], which is poured over the sliced duck. (This dish is today the speciality of the house at ''[[La Tour d'Argent]]''.){{cite web|url=http://fxcuisine.com/default.asp?Display=13 |title=Duck Tour d'Argent |publisher=Fxcuisine.com |date=1 December 2006 |accessdate=27 April 2011}}
'''''Ortolans sur canapés''''', [[Ortolan bunting#Gastronomy|ortolans]] (now a [[protected species]]) on [[toast]].
'''''Aubergines à l'espagnole''''' is a dish of [[aubergine]] shells filled with chopped aubergine, tomato and [[ham]], [[gratin]]éed with [[Gruyère (cheese)|gruyère]].
'''''Cassolette princesse''''', (a.k.a. '''''Cassolette argenteuil'''''), A [[cassolette]] with a border of [[duchesse potatoes]] and an [[asparagus]] filling in [[cream sauce]].
'''''[[Bombe glacée]]''''' is an [[ice cream]] dessert. – Source: ==Re-creation== [[Australia]]n chef [[Shannon Bennett]] attempted to recreate the banquet in 2002. It took six months to plan and required some changes due to key ingredients and wines no longer being available. Even using the nearest modern equivalent ingredients and wines, the cost of the meal was [[Australian dollar|$]]7,500 per person. The [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] broadcast the documentary ''Three Emperors Dinner'' about the original banquet and the modern recreation in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/tv/documentaries/stories/s814454.htm|title=Three Emperors Dinner|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation|date=4 March 2003}} ==See also== * [[Banquet of Chestnuts]] * [[List of dining events]] * [[Nobel Banquet]] ==Gallery== {{Gallery |File: Café anglais.jpg|[[Café Anglais (Paris)|Café Anglais]] in 1913 |File:Kaiser Wilhelm I. .JPG|[[William I, German Emperor|King William I of Prussia]] |File:Alexander II 1870 by Sergei Lvovich Levitsky.jpg|[[Alexander II of Russia|Tsar Alexander II of Russia]] |File:Kramskoy Alexander III.jpg|Tsarevich Alexander
(later [[Alexander III of Russia|Tsar Alexander III]]) |File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-R15449, Otto von Bismarck.jpg|[[Otto von Bismarck]] }} ==References== {{Reflist|refs= {{cite book | last=Frost | first=W. | last2=Laing | first2=J. | title=Gastronomy, Tourism and the Media | publisher=Channel View Publications | series=Aspects of Tourism | year=2016 | isbn=978-1-84541-576-1 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tiipDAAAQBAJ&pg=PT57 | page=57}} }} {{portalbar|Food|History|Paris}} [[Category:Dining events]] [[Category:French cuisine]] [[Category:1867 in France]] [[Category:High society]] [[Category:June 1867 events]]

'''Two-way satellite time and frequency transfer''' ('''TWSTFT''') is a high-precision long distance [[time and frequency transfer]] mechanism used between [[time bureau]]x to determine and distribute time and frequency standards.
{{As of|2003}} TWSTFT is being evaluated as an alternative to be used by the [[Bureau International des Poids et Mesures]] in the determination of [[International Atomic Time]] (TAI), as a complement to the current standard method of simultaneous observations of [[GPS]] transmissions.
==External links== {{Portal|Time}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20021001184919/http://www.npl.co.uk/time/twstft.html TWSTFT page at the National Physical Laboratory] * [https://www.ptb.de/cms/en/ptb/fachabteilungen/abt4/fb-44/ag-442/international-time-comparisons/two-way-satellite-time-and-frequency-transfer-twstft.html TWSTFT page at the Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt] * [http://tf.nist.gov/time/twoway.htm NIST TWSTFT page] * [http://www.usno.navy.mil/USNO/time/twstt TWSTFT page at the US Naval Observatory]

[[File:Tom Lea - 2000 Yard Stare.jpg|thumb|right|"In debating social policy through the language of war, we often forget the moral reality of war." − [[James Childress]]. A 1944 illustration by [[Thomas C. Lea III]] of [[World War II]]: "[[Thousand-yard stare|The 2000 Yard Stare]]".]]
The use of '''war as metaphor''' is a longstanding literary and rhetorical [[Trope (literature)|trope]]. In political usage, [[war]] [[metaphor]]s are used to manage a perceived societal problem, with the concept taking the place of an individual or state enemy in true war.
[[James Childress]] describes the use of war as a metaphor as a dilemma: "In debating social policy through the language of war, we often forget the moral reality of war."<ref name="jfc"/> One fundamental problem is that it is often unclear when the "war" is over.<ref name="sr-20160518"/>
The [[Cultural Revolution]] in China 1966−1976, which initially was launched as a "War against Revisionism", is a discouraging example of a metaphorical war against "-isms".<ref name="sr-20160518"/>
== Examples == Examples of war used as a metaphor, often on the form "War on..." or "War against...":
* "[[Customs war]]", also known as a "toll war" or "tariff war", a type of economic conflict between two or more states. * "[[Trade war]]" * "[[War on crime|War on Crime]]", 1930s, [[J. Edgar Hoover]] * "[[Cold War]]" (1947—1991), a period of hostility between the two dominant [[superpower]]s at the time, the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]]. The Cold War in itself was never a war, but several [[proxy war]]s were carried out by both sides over the period. * The [[Cultural Revolution]] (1966−1976) in China was launched as a "War against Revisionism"<ref name="sr-20160518"/> Marshall [[ Lin Biao]] is given credit for inspiring war metaphors when he said in 1965, at the outset of the movement, "The battlefield of the Cultural Revolution cannot call a ceasefire. This is a war without that option."<ref> {{citation|author=Xing Lu|title=Rhetoric of the Chinese Cultural Revolution: The Impact on Chinese Thought, Culture, and Communication|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GO5HrrJC_aMC&pg=PA91|date=January 2004|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press|isbn=978-1-57003-543-2|pages=91}}</ref> * [[Jimmy Carter]]'s application of "war" as metaphor for the [[1973 oil crisis|energy crisis of 1974]]{{clarify|How was it used? Add a quote from the source if possible.|date=May 2016}} described in ''[[Metaphors We Live By]]'' by George Lakoff and Mark Johnson describe * "[[War on Poverty]]", an unofficial name for legislation first introduced by United States president [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] during his [[State of the Union address]] on 8 January 1964. * "[[War on Cancer]]", combined effort to decrease cancer mortality through improved prevention, detection, and treatment * "[[War on Drugs]]", US term referring to efforts to curtail illegal drug trade * "[[War on Gangs]]", national movement in the US to reduce gang-related activity, gang violence, and gang drug involvement * "[[Culture war]]" (1991, 2000s), various conflicts and demographic trends in US history * "[[War of ideas]]" (1993), [[Heritage Foundation]] analyst James A. Phillips used the term "war of ideas" in describing the pivotal role played by the [[National Endowment for Democracy]] (NED) in the ideological battle for the protection of democracy. * "War on Terrorism" or "[[War on Terror]]" (2001−2013) coined in 2001 by then United States [[President of the United States|president]] [[George W. Bush]] after the [[September 11 attacks|terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001]] to mobilize an international military campaign. In 2013, President [[Barack Obama]] announced that the United States was no longer pursuing a War on Terror, as the military focus should be on specific enemies rather than a tactic. * "War on [[Graffiti]]", municipal initiative described by [[Toronto]] mayor [[Rob Ford]] * "War on [[Automobile|Cars]]", municipal initiative described by [[Toronto]] mayor [[Rob Ford]] * "[[War on Want]]" is an anti-poverty charity based in London * [[War on I-4 (arena football)|War on I-4]], nickname for rivalry between [[Tampa Bay Storm]] and the [[Orlando Predators]] in the [[Arena Football League]] * [[Emu War|War against Emus]] * "[[Global War on Error]]", a campaign to eliminate [[aviation]] errors. The term was coined by [[Tony Kern]].
Some "wars" are not proclaimed but rather a label used by adversaries: * "[[War against Islam]]" (also called the "War on Islam"), a term coined in the 1990s and popularized after 2001 to describe a perceived campaign to harm, weaken or annihilate the societal system of Islam, using military, economic, social and cultural means. * "[[Christmas controversy|War on Christmas]]", term in the US to describe perennial controversy occurring around Christmas * ''[[War on Whistleblowers]]'', a 2013 documentary by [[Robert Greenwald]]. * "[[The War Within (disambiguation)|The War Within]]", may refer to several things * "[[War on Women]]", an expression in US politics used to describe certain Republican Party policies as a wide-scale effort to restrict women's rights, especially reproductive rights * "War on Democracy" from the title ''[[The War on Democracy]]'', a 2007 documentary film directed by Christopher Martin and John Pilger * "War on Secrecy" from the title ''[[WikiLeaks: Inside Julian Assange's War on Secrecy]]'', a 2011 book by [[David Leigh (journalist)|David Leigh]] and [[Luke Harding]] telling the story of [[Julian Assange]], [[WikiLeaks]], and the leak by [[Chelsea Manning]] * "[[War on Coal]]", a phrase used by the coal industry and its supporters to describe what they claim is an effort by the [[Obama administration]] to impose stringent regulations on coal power in the United States * "[[War on Cops]]", a phrase used by Bill Johnson, Executive Director of [[National Association of Police Organizations]]. Also called "War on Police". Similar rhetoric was used by [[Donald Trump]], [[Ted Cruz]], and [[Scott Walker (politician)|Scott Walker]].<ref>[[Radley Balko]]. "[https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-watch/wp/2015/09/10/once-again-there-is-no-war-on-cops-and-those-who-claim-otherwise-are-playing-a-dangerous-game/ Once again: There is no 'war on cops.' And those who claim otherwise are playing a dangerous game.]", ''[[The Washington Post]]'', 10 September 2015. Retrieved 12 July 2016.</ref> * "War on [[Science]]", used variously to describe academic [[postmodernism]]'s criticism of objective reality<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Sidky|first1=H.|title=The War on Science, Anti-Intellectualism, and 'Alternative Ways of Knowing' in 21st-Century America|journal=Skeptical Inquirer|date=2018|volume=42|issue=2|pages=38–43|url=https://www.csicop.org/si/show/e_war_on_science_anti-intellectualism_and_alternative_ways_of_knowing_in_21|accessdate=13 May 2018}}</ref> or political opposition to the conclusions of science.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mooney|first1=Chris|title=The Republican War on Science|date=2005|publisher=Basic Books|isbn=9780465046751}}</ref>
==Further reading== * Childress, James F. "The war metaphor in public policy"<ref name="jfc"/> *Steinert, Heinz. 2003. "The Indispensable Metaphor of War: On Populist Politics and the Contradictions of the State's Monopoly of Force," ''Theoretical Criminology'' '''7'''.3 (2003) p. 265-291. *Thomas, Ruth P. 1984. "War as metaphor in ''La Princesse de Montpensier''", ''Forum for Modern Language Studies'' '''20'''.4 p. 323-332.
== References == <references> <ref name="jfc"> {{cite encyclopedia |last=Childress |first=James F.|editor-last=Ficarrotta |editor-first=J. Carl |date=2001 |encyclopedia=The Leader's Imperative: Ethics, Integrity, and Responsibility |title=The War Metaphor in Public Policy: Some Moral Relections |url=https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/purduepress_ebooks/6 |publisher=Purdue University Press |isbn= 9781612491394 |format=PDF |pages=181–197 |access-date=July 25, 2018}} </ref> <ref name="sr-20160518">"[https://sverigesradio.se/sida/artikel.aspx?programid=438&artikel=6434947 Vad har Kina lärt av kulturrevolutionen?]", professor [[Michael Schoenhals]] in ''[[Godmorgon världen!]]'', [[Sveriges radio]], 18 May 2016. Retrieved 23 maj 2016. (In Swedish)</ref> </references>
